properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Big Beach near Mallacoota.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • Department of Environment Land Water and Planning Wildlife Officers are monitoring the whale.
  • You should exercise additional caution until the whale has decomposed.
Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches. Any shark over 2m in length is considered dangerous.
What you should do:
  • If you see a shark report the shark sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water. Donâ€™t remain in the water with bleeding wounds.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
  • Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring the area for increased shark activity.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 22/07/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

For more information on staying safe around sharks, visit www.vfa.vic.gov.au/shark-smart.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - DANGEROUS ANIMAL - Avoid the Area
Incident Location: Big Beach east of Mallacoota
Issue Date: Monday 18 July 2022, 11:05 am
Next Update: Friday 22 July 2022, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20960/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Big Beach near Mallacoota.

- Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
- Department of Environment Land Water and Planning Wildlife Officers are monitoring the whale.
- You should exercise additional caution until the whale has decomposed.


Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches. Any shark over 2m in length is considered dangerous.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Doncaster East, Donvale, Templestowe.

  • There is a house fire in May Street Doncaster East. 
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond. 
  • If you are sensitive to smoke or you live with someone who is sensitive to smoke, you should close windows and doors. Turn off heating and cooling systems.
  • To prevent the smell of smoke entering your home or business, close windows and doors.  
Impacts in your area: 
  • The following road is closed: May Street, Doncaster East.
  • Traffic in the area may be affected.
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

The next update is expected by 20/07/2022 08:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Gippsland Lakes and the Gippsland Coast from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water in the Gippsland Lakes and the Ninety Mile Beach from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo.

  • The levels of blue green algae within the Gippsland Lakes have decreased to well below the safe contact thresholds. The entire Gippsland Lakes system and Ninety Mile Beach is now safe for recreational contact with water.
  • However as toxins from the algae can accumulate in seafood after a bloom has dispersed, advice regarding the consumption of specific seafood still applies.
  • Do not consume crustaceans (such as prawns, crabs and bugs) and shellfish caught inside the Gippsland Lakes or within 10 nautical miles of the shore between Mcloughlins Beach and Marlo.
  • Finfish caught from within the Gippsland Lakes should be rinsed thoroughly in fresh water and the guts and gills removed before cooking or freezing.
  • Ingesting these toxins can lead to serious illness. Cooking or freezing does not destroy the toxins.
What you should do:
  • Visit betterhealth.vic.gov.au for more information. 
  • Keep up-to-date with algae information at www.water.vic.gov.au/waterways-and-catchments/rivers-estuaries-and-waterways/blue-green-algae
Protect your health:
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.



This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 21/07/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/harmful-algal-blooms 
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE
Incident Location: Gippsland Lakes and the Gippsland Coast from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo
Issue Date: Thursday 30 June 2022, 03:39 pm
Next Update: Thursday 21 July 2022, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20924/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water in the Gippsland Lakes and the Ninety Mile Beach from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo. 

- The levels of blue green algae within the Gippsland Lakes have decreased to well below the safe contact thresholds. The entire Gippsland Lakes system and Ninety Mile Beach is now safe for recreational contact with water.
- However as toxins from the algae can accumulate in seafood after a bloom has dispersed, advice regarding the consumption of specific seafood still applies.


- Do not consume crustaceans (such as prawns, crabs and bugs) and shellfish caught inside the Gippsland Lakes or within 10 nautical miles of the shore between Mcloughlins Beach and Marlo.
- Finfish caught from within the Gippsland Lakes should be rinsed thoroughly in fresh water and the guts and gills removed before cooking or freezing.
- Ingesting these toxins can lead to serious illness. Cooking or freezing does not destroy the toxins.

properties.location: Gippsland Lakes and the Gippsland Coast from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Coast Marlo to the Victoria-New South Wales Border
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for coastal water from Marlo to the Victoria-New South Wales Border.  

  • The levels of blue green algae within the Gippsland Lakes have decreased to below safe contact thresholds. The entire Gippsland Lakes system and ocean is now safe for recreational contact with the water. 
  • It is important to note that advice regarding the consumption of specific seafood remains in place.
Do not eat prawns from affected waters.

These prawns may have come from the Gippsland Lakes and Ninety Mile Beach area and may contain toxins from the recent blue green algae bloom.

Do to not consume prawns caught within 10 nautical miles of the shore between Mcloughlins Beach and the Victoria-New South Wales border.
What you should do:
  • Visit betterhealth.vic.gov.au for more information. 
  • Keep up-to-date with algae information at www.water.vic.gov.au/waterways-and-catchments/rivers-estuaries-and-waterways/blue-green-algae
Protect your health:
If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.  

This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 21/07/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Issue Date: Thursday 30 June 2022, 03:38 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20925/moreinfo

This message is being issued for coastal water from Marlo to the Victoria-New South Wales Border.  

- The levels of blue green algae within the Gippsland Lakes have decreased to below safe contact thresholds. The entire Gippsland Lakes system and ocean is now safe for recreational contact with the water. 
- It is important to note that advice regarding the consumption of specific seafood remains in place.



Do not eat prawns from affected waters.

These prawns may have come from the Gippsland Lakes and Ninety Mile Beach area and may contain toxins from the recent blue green algae bloom.

Do to not consume prawns caught within 10 nautical miles of the shore between Mcloughlins Beach and the Victoria-New South Wales border.
